document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the subgenus Aleochara Gravenhorst of the parasitoid rove beetle genus Aleochara Gravenhorst of Japan (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the subgenus Aleochara Gravenhorst of the parasitoid rove beetle genus Aleochara Gravenhorst of Japan (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Aleochara parens
Sharp, 1874
: 6
(original description; type locality: Japan , not specified); Fenyes, 1920 : 399 [as subgenus
Aleochara
(s. str.); catalogue of world species of Aleocharinae ];

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Lectotype , here designated, male, “SYN- /
TYPE
[ BRL ] // Japan / G. Lewis // Lectotype / Aleochara parens / Sharp, 1974 / des.
Maruyama / 2011
” (abdominal segments VIII-X and aedeagus dissected and mounted in Euparal by MM) ( BMNH ). Pararectotypes,
1 male
,
1 female
(pinned together) “SYN- /
TYPE
[ BRL ] / / Japan / G. Lewis // Sharp Coll. / 1905 - 313 // Aleochara / parens / Ind. Typ / D.S.” (PC changed to new one, whole body soaked in KOH solution, mouthparts dissected, elytron removed, median lobe broken, by PR) ( BMNH );
1 male
,
3 females
, “SYN- /
TYPE
[ BRL ] // Japan / G. Lewis // Sharp Coll. / 1905 - 313 // Aleochara / parens / Ind. Typ / D.S.” (two females glued on one PC on which written as “ Aleochara / parens / Japan Lewis”) ( BMNH ).

Diagnosis.
Aleochara parens
is similar to the other species, especially
A. postica
and
A. coreana
, but this species can be separated from them by the combination of the following characteristics: body small to relatively large in size (
A. postica
and
A. coreana
rarely small in size); body usually uniformly brownish brown to blackish brown in color (not
A. coreana
and part of
A. postica
); head of dorsal surface evenly rather densely and shallowly punctured (not
A. postica
); elytra sometimes with darkened but relatively ambiguous maculations on lateral sides of each elytron (not
A. coreana
); median lobe of male aedeagus bulbous (not
A. postica
), complex sclerites not reaching near bottom of median lobe (not
A. coreana
); female spermatheca C-shaped (not
A. postica
), apical invagination of spermatheca deep and subconical in shape (not
A. coreana
and
A. postica
). This species is often found on islands distant from mainland of Japan , except for Yaeyama-shotô Islands, the Ryûkyûs, southwestern part of Japan .

Body ( Figs 4 , 13 ): fusiform, robust, small to large in size; dorsal surface weakly glossy and pubescent, without any kind of micro-reticulation, rather finely punctured. Color ( Figs 4 , 13 ): usually uniformly brownish brown to blackish brown, but elytra variable in color pattern, generally pale brown to dark brown uniformly (sometimes infuscate laterally and basally to form somewhat indistinct dark maculations); antennae with antennomeres I–III yellowish brown to dark reddish brown, antennomere IV much darker, antennomeres V–XI slightly darker than those of I–III but covered densely with minute whitish setae; mouth parts and legs yellowish brown to dark brownish brown; pubescence yellowish brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 72–78. Terminalia of
Aleochara
( Aleochara )
parens
: 72, male tergite VIII, dorsal view; 73, female tergite VIII, dorsal view; 74, male sternite VIII, ventral view; 75, female sternite VIII, ventral view; 76, median lobe of male aedeagus, lateral view; 77, ditto, parameral view; 78, female spermatheca. Scale bars: 0.5 mm (72–75); 0.2 mm (76–77); 0.1 mm (78).

subSubSection.paragraph: Host records. No host record is available.

Remarks for type material.
There are seven possible syntypes of
A. parens
. However, three of them were dissected inadequately by PR and in very bad condition. The remaining four specimens included one male specimen with its aedeagus in good condition, which is designated as the lectotype here (
Fig. 111
).
